revised_title: The Role of the Face-Cell Area in Facial Recognition and Discrimination in Monkeys
tldr: The study investigates the role of the 'face-cell' area in the superior temporal sulcus of macaque monkeys in facial recognition and discrimination. The researchers found that removing this area did not significantly impair the monkeys' ability to recognize faces or perform face-related tasks, suggesting that this area may be more involved in perceiving facial expressions and bearing rather than basic face recognition.
